"How is she doing it? Does she write down her daily activities in a diary and take ideas from different moments in her life to use them in her characters? Is she taking notes from perhaps her favourite works of literature and combining everything she learned into one work? Did she read books on sociology before writing chapters?" All these thoughts constantly popped up intomy head while I was watching Sangatsu no lion season 2. Because for a work to portray emotions of this much variety and to convey it in some of the easiest and most natural ways possible is truly something amazing. The writer understands what it's like to be a human. In some instances, some of the portrayals might be a little too over the top but I'll come back to that later. What is important is that Sangatsu no lion matters. It can impact people in a positive way. It can remind you of how you used to think in the past, it can deliver comments on how your current way of thinking is wrong and it can be a guideline for what you should do in the future. By all means, Sangatsu no lion, in my opinion, is one of the greatest animes ever made and something that'll stay in the top of my 'favourites list' for now. Since Sangatsu is a show about thought progression and human interaction, I can't talk about this show properly without talking about myself. So I hope you will pardon me for making this a little too much about myself if it is that way by the end of the review. 


Changes from Season 1:


When I finished watching Sangatsu no lion season 1, I was quite mesmerized. Sangatsu no lion created one of the most awkward and relatable main characters ever in Rei Kiriyama. Through Rei's journey, we remembered what it was like to grow up to be what we are now and for a lot of people it may have been a guide to what they should do next.By no means is 3 gatsu no lion something most people would love to watch. By the time season 1 ended, there were people who loved the show and there were people who didn't like it at all. A lot of people didn't appreciate the transitions the show made from being depressing to being weirdly cheerful from time to time. Although some of that did bother me, the show overwhelmed me with its good sides. After finishing season 1 Rei's development hit a point where he couldn't be the same person he was in season 1. The theme's of depression sorrounding him and his search for an ideal idea inside his heart couldn't be dragged forward too much. This is why I was also worried that season 2 might not be as good as season 1. I was worried that if Sangatsu no lion lost its heartwarming depression (you realizing your themes of depression are understood by another person is often heartwarming) it would be just another show with nothing special going for it. The season takes a few episodes to get going. But ultimately season 2 proves me wrong and goes to a level that far exceeds my expectations. While Rei's development reached a solid point, this season gives time to most of the other characters who required development. Characters like Nikaidou, Hina and Akari get a lot more development as the author explores each of their individual problems/insecurities. While depression and the feeling of relatable content remained, the show added another dimension to its progress. To explain this I need to go back to a quote from another show. I remember my favourite quote in the Psycho-pass series came from the far inferior season 2. Coming from Nobuchika Ginoza it was something like,

"The shortcut to growing up fast is accepting things the way they are." At that point, the line hit me like a truck. It didn't tell me anything new. But it suddenly expressed something I wanted to word for a long time. I finally understood why some of the adults can't understand when I'm trying to tell them about the various concepts I imagine. They grew up and hence forgot what it's like to dream a false hope of being in a different reality. That didn't mean I was okay with that sort of thinking. I do believe people should keep searching things inside of themselves without easily accepting what everyone else finds normal. In a way Sangatsu no lion season 1 was a reflection of my beliefs. Rei knew what the normal things to do and feel would be. Yet he kept searching for a solution that will finally give him the peace he is looking for. He never forced himself to adapt to things just because that's the normal thing to do. He craved for an imaginary sensation he didn't feel before. In a way, he was yet to understand how everything worked and how everyone felt. So he made mistakes along the way to learn things in what I believe to be 'the proper way'. After his development hits a certain point at the end of season 1 and he can accept himself for who he is, the show evolves alongside Rei. Most of the conflicts Rei had in season 1 was mostly the fruit of his own nature of overthinking things. It was a kind of psychological stress that came naturally with the circumstances he had to face while growing up. This applies to Kyoko's problems as well who just grew up to be strange because she didn't accept the direction her life took. This time around the problems revolve around the more apparent ones we have in our society. By the end of season 1, the show already had us accepting things to be the way they are by highlighting all the bright sides that might make living worth it. This time it added another dimension by exploring common social problems and criticizing common social beliefs. It also presented a story of fighting sickness that almost brought me to tears. In a way Sangatsu no lion season 2 advances on the social side of things and goes on to become more than just a story. It finds itself being much more of an inspirational show this time. 

As I pointed out before Rei understands his worth a lot more this season. His transition also adds to the show. Rei's narration is beautifully done. He is slowly developing into a protagonist who would be ideal in anyone's eyes. He still has a long way to go but that's just more reason why the show is beautiful. No matter how much progress you go through it never really is enough. There's always room for more improvement. Through Rei's own self critical self we are reminded of just that. Finding reasons to love doing what you do is important. This is something that gets a lot more light in this season. If you search strongly, you might find yours too. 


Story:


If you think I gave away every theme there is about this show, you are largely mistaken. Sangatsu has at least one unique theme every episode. So the more you search for, the more you get out of this show. As for the main story, I will personally divide the story this season into 4 sections. One will deal with Hina's personal life problems that will last for almost the entirety of the season. One will deal with Nikaidou's sickness that was revealed during season 1. The duration of this might be small but the impact is probably the strongest out of everything the season delivers. The 3rd section is everything shogi related. The 4th section is about adapting with change. Something we get to see at the final few episodes of the season. Sangatsu is more about experiencing the story rather than simply watching or reading it. So without giving away too many spoilers, I will let you experience everything for yourself. 

The shogi in season 2 is as good as season 1 if not better. I'll say it again that the main appeal of Sangatsu no lion is understanding people and understanding yourself. The shogi plays a major role in doing so as well. Unlike most sports/game related shows Sangatsu gives a lot of focus to all the players playing shogi this season. Details of how they had to grow up. their habits, their thought process, their worries-all of these is presented beautifully which helps you understand and be one with the characters by finding similarities with yourself. 

Random quote from episode 2 to explain what I mean,

“Everyone who’s gotten their butts kicked in a title match will always lose their composure for a bit. That’s just how it is. ‘At this rate, I’ll just lose.’ That is what they realize in between matches of a series. They have to break themselves apart and reconstruct it again from the shattered pieces. They start over from square one.”

 This is a perfect example of the show exploring in-game psychology and being able to connect it with other everyday emotions, Portraying the difficulties of what it means to be a professional and what it takes to stay in the game throughout your life.  It's not only the shogi that's getting the focus, but also the human beings playing it.

Like most people, the only thing I didn't like in season 1 was the attempted comedy. I understood why they did it but it wasn't always easy to watch. The comedy in season 2 was a massive improvement. Whenever they made certain scenes a little too melodramatic and cringy they followed it up with heartwarming comedy. Some of these moments might not make you laugh but they do a great job changing the tempo and resetting things to the way we like it. For me, the only way to do comedy right is to keep the lines hidden and make it unpredictable. Sangatsu uses its awkwardness as a tool for comedy this season which makes it much funnier than it's previous season. There's also gimmick comedy that worked well in the form of Noguchi. What also helps is every episode has a perfect balance of comedy and darkness this time. So the series maintains its consistency throughout. This is why I was able to accept the comedy a lot more this time around. 


Art and Animation:


I think I praised what the source material offers quite a lot. The art is just as good as everything else. Characters are drawn beautifully and all of them are well detailed. The environment is used for storytelling and the scenes just take you to another place. But enough of that. Chika Umino did everything well. But portraying a concept such as Sangatsu's in animated form is not an easy thing to do. It can't be like just another show. It has to make the audience experience things the characters are experiencing. The anime wouldn't as good as it is if Studio Shaft didn't do such a remarkable job. The Visual imagery of Sangatsu no lion is just outstanding. The one word to describe it would be 'surreal'. It's like breaking down the real world and creating something that can be molded and painted into whatever you want. Every emotion is highlighted in their own unique ways. During important monologues, the screen shows the face of the character listening/talking/thinking in different angles portraying the shift of emotions as the monologue goes on.  That really draws you into whatever they are saying. Shaft also did a great job making a chapter by chapter adaption which is probably the only right way to adapt this show.


Sounds:


Not gonna lie, I'm a guy who is musically open to very few genres. But no matter what Sangatsu no lion does, I seem to like it. It was musical works such as 'Answer' and 'En fermant les yeux' that made me want to watch the show in the first place. I liked all 4 of the openings and endings this season. There's not much to say about the soundtrack. The soundtrack just fits so well with the overall atmosphere. If either one of these attributes were to go wrong it wouldn't be possible to achieve the connection Sangatsu no lion achieves with its audience. The show can make me draw emotions using its music. It can make me feel things with its music and at the end of the day this what music is supposed to do. It is supposed to soothe.It is supposed to connect with the listeners. Full marks to the production team. 


Characters: 


With season 1 mostly focusing on Rei and Shimada, this season does justice to Akari, Hinata, Nikaidou, Mr. Yanagihara and many more characters. We also learn a little bit more about mysterious meijin Souya who influences Rei a lot this season.

Akari: After the death of her mother and grandmother, Akari had to play the role of a mother figure for Hina and Momo. Her insecurities and worries are portrayed quite well in this season making people empathize with her. She has room for development and judging by what I was given thus far, she will develop into a much stronger character if we get another season.

Nikaidou: You understand everything Nikaidou stands for as the season progresses. He didn't get a whole lot of time dedicated to him. But they made the most out of what was.

Mr. Yanagihara: Sangatsu produces another lovable character. The episodes dedicated to this old man are simply amazing. It wasn't just old man thought too. Most of us probably think what he thinks already. But this is where we truly understand his pain as he had to carry those thoughts of burden for a long amount of time and still find a reason to be happy everytime.

Hinata: Before I talk about Hinata's development this season, I want to talk about something Sangatsu no lion made me realize in its previous season. In those episodes where Rei reveals his lonely school life and how people avoided him and vice versa, I really felt bad about myself. It was the feeling of regret. I also knew children like that who were avoided in class during my primary and middle school days. I somewhat knew I should talk to them but I didn't care quite enough. I was also afraid to be judged by others and thus decided to be a nothing for them just like everyone else. I regret not helping them during those times after watching Sanatsu. Sangatsu never directly told me how wrong I was back then. But Ms. Umino immediately picks up on it and has an arc dedicated to school problems. A that story not only shows us an example of how to fix things but it is also an example of how things can go wrong. Throughout this arc we see the development of Hina as she becomes a fine main female lead for the show. She takes on the role Rei played during last season and keeps everything we loved about season 1 alive at the same time. Rei's own development centers a lot around Hina. Her character keeps growing as you keep on watching the season. 

Rei: Rei is as lovable as always and it's nice to see him finally enjoy his life. The role he plays is quite different this season. But the guy cannot stop being relatable as always. Rei's voice actor does a phenomenal job once again as Rei's narration inside his head is one of the best things about this show. Rei grows some more this season and gets closer to becoming the person he wants to be in the story and we want to be in real life. 

Momo: Momo is the greatest gift anime has given to mankind. 

Overall, the characters were really great once again this season. They are what makes Sangatsu no lion so unique in the first place.


Enjoyment:


Sangatsu no lion has this strong descriptive style of writing. It's like even though now you should be able to solve {(12+4)*64-24}/10 in a matter of 10-15 seconds max, it wasn't always the same for you. You probably had to do each operation one at a time when you were a lot younger. Thoughts are a sum of smaller pieces of thoughts. We forget with time that these smaller thoughts will eventually lead to many more larger thoughts. Thus we often bury these insignificant thoughts thinking they won't matter. Sangatsu breaks down those thoughts to a much smaller level with its descriptive monologues. You may think most of it is unnecessary but if you think about it, you realize how significant they are when it comes to the characters feeling what they feel.It tells multiple stories that cohesively deliver strong themes. This is not something you write just to entertain the crowd. You can only write something like that when you are writing down a piece of you. So how enjoyable is Sangatsu no lion season 2? "If we go by our usual answer of enjoyable = entertaining that it probably isn't the most enjoyable show. If we look beyond that, it is a very enjoyable show as you experience how thoughts can be conveyed and learn a few things about writing yourself alongside some very heartwarming in-story content." I said something like that during last season but this season actually had a fair amount of entertaining content. So it is very enjoyable both ways.


Favourite Quote:

“Gaining and losing things are an unavoidable part of life for everybody. You feel joy, you feel disappointment and it repeats. And that’s how you learn how to handle your feelings. Disappointment and loneliness are necessary emotions. Because of loneliness people muster courage and reach out to a new world. Doing that is like reaching out as a baby does, and expands it’s small world.”

-Eisaku Noguchi 


Conclusion: Sangatsu was written in 2007 and this is why a lot of the approaches are old. For example, I know people will complain about things like "Why isn't that girl just talking to her friend over the phone." I have read complains like this already. But when you consider the time it was written I'm sure most of these things will make sense. There's not much more I can say about it. It might make you smile, it might make you cry and it will give you cooking lessons. I like everything about the show and I can make everything they did seem like a likable thing because this is exactly how it was to me. Hopefully, this will be exactly the same for a lot more people yet to watch this show. I'd be pretty proud of myself If I could apply everything I've learned/got reminded of by watching Sangatsu in real life. Therefore, I would strongly recommend everyone to give this show a shot and to see if you can get something out of it.  Thank you Chika Umino and Shaft for giving us a 'slice of life' in quite a literal form.

প্রথমেই শোওটির গল্পে আসা যাক। রেই কিরিয়ামা একজন পেশাদার শোগি খেলোয়াড়। শোগি খেলাটি জাপানি দাবা হিসেবে পরিচিত।রেই একজন পেশাদার শোগি খেলোয়াড় হয়ে ওঠে যখন সে মিডল স্কুলে পড়ে এবং তার সাফল্য শীঘ্রই তাকে তার প্রজন্মের সবচেয়ে প্রতিভাবান খেলোয়াড়দের মধ্যে একজনের স্থান দেয়। তার বাবা-মা ও বোন একটি ট্র্যাফিক দুর্ঘটনায় মারা গেলে, তার পিতার বন্ধু কোডা তাকে গ্রহণ করে এবং শোগীতে তার শিক্ষক হিসেবে কাজ করে। পারিবারিক কারণে মিডিল স্কুল সম্পন্ন হওয়ার পর, রেই স্বাধীন হওয়ার সিদ্ধান্ত নেয় এবং এক বছরের বিলম্বের পর হাই স্কুল যোগদান করে। শোগি খেলা রেই এর শখ এর কাজ না হলেও জীবনের প্রয়োজনে তাকে শোগিকেই তার একমাত্র অবলম্বন হিসেবে স্বীকার করতে হয়। প্রতিটি শোগি match এর মাধ্যমে আমরা রেই ও তার প্রতিদ্বন্দ্বীদের ব্যাপারে কিছু জিনিস জানতে পারি। শোগি দিনে দিনে জনপ্রিয়তা হারিয়ে ফেলায় একজন শোগি খেলোয়াড়ের জন্য খ্যাতির ছটা থেকে বেরিয়ে আসা কতটা কষ্টের হতে পারে তা এখানে তুলে ধরা হয়েছে। Sangatsu নিজেদের চরিত্রদের গভীর মানসিক বিপাকে ফেলে তা থেকে বেরিয়ে আসার দৃষ্টান্ত স্থাপন করে। এর মাধ্যমে দর্শকরা তাদের নিজেদের সংগ্রামের সাথে কাহিনীর মিল কিছুটাও যাতে পেতে পারে সে উদ্দেশ্যেই এমন করা হয়েছে। যে বিষয়গুলি নিয়ে কথা বলা হয় তা এমন কোন বিষয় নয় যা আগে কেউ চিন্তা করেনি। কিন্ত এটি যা করে তা হল আপনি যেসব বছরগুলিতে এখানকার চরিত্রগুলির মত চিন্তা করেছিলেন, সে সময়ের চিন্তাগুলোর সাথে বর্তমান চিন্তাভাবনার সম্পর্ক স্থাপন করা। এটি একটি যাত্রা যেখানে আপনি নিজেকে আবিষ্কার করতে পারেন।যারা একই পর্যায়গুলির মাধ্যমে যাচ্ছে তাদের চিন্তে পারবেন ও তাদেরকে আরও ভালো করে বুঝতে পারবেন। Sangatsu এর পরিবেশ পরিবর্তন চোখে পড়ার মত একটি বিষয়। খুবই বিষণ্ণ একটি দৃশ্য হতে Over the top হাসানোর চেষ্টায় পরিচালিত দৃশ্যে শোটি অনেক সহজে নিজেকে পরিবর্তন করতে পারে। তার মূল কারণ দুঃখ ও প্রশান্তির মাঝে ভারসাম্য রাখার প্রয়োজনীয়তা। তাছাড়া সিজন ১ এর কমেডি বেশ দুর্বল হলেও সিজন ২ এ কমেডিতে এর ব্যাপক উন্নতি ঘটে। 


চিত্রকর্ম চমৎকার। পরিবেশগত বর্ণনার ব্যবহার এবং তাদের চিত্রিত করে সুন্দরভাবে দর্শকদের কাছে উষ্ণতার এবং বদ্ধতার অনুভুতি পৌঁছে দেওয়ার কৌশল বেশ অসাধারণ ছিল। এটি চরিত্রের কল্পনার সাথে দর্শকের কল্পনা একীভূত করে। উন্নত এনিমেশন এর মাধ্যমে বাস্তব অনুভূতি এর অনন্য পরিবেশন দিতে সক্ষম হয়েছে Sangatsu no lion. মিউজিক এর কথা ইতিমধ্যে বলা হয়েছে। মিউজিক এর মাধমে বিষণ্ণতা ও আনন্দ কে সঠিকভাবে উপস্থাপন করতে শোটি সফল হয়েছে। গানগুলি শুধু শুনতে ভালো শোনায় যে তা নয়। এগুলোর মূল গুন হলো গল্প বলার সামর্থ্য। সমস্যা থাকা স্বাভাবিক এবং একই সমস্যায় ভুগতে থাকা অন্য চরিত্রকে দেখলে আমরা চরিত্রটির উন্নয়নের মাধ্যমে নিজেদের মধ্যে সে উন্নয়ন আনার সুযোগ লাভ করি। কেননা কোন চরিত্র কাল্পনিক হলেও তার লেখক ঠিকই এমন পরিস্থিতির মুখোমুখি হয়েছেন বলে চরিত্রটি লিখতে পেরেছেন। এতোটুকু জানলেই আমাদের মাঝে কোন সমস্যা মোকাবেলা করার শক্তি জন্মে। কেননা আমরা বুঝতে পারি আমরা একা নই। এমন মানসিক অবস্থা তৈরি করার জন্য sangatsu এর সাউন্ডট্র্যাক অনেক গুরুত্বপূর্ণ অবদান পালন করে। 


এখন আমি এই অনুষ্ঠানের আমার প্রিয় দিক সম্পর্কে কথা বলি। চরিত্র! অল্প সময়ের মধ্যে Sangatsu এর চরিত্রগুলি অনেক গভীরতা লাভ করে। রেই কিরিয়ামা সফল অথচ অসুখী কারণ জীবনে আনন্দের ছোঁওয়া সে হারিয়ে ফেলেছে। বেঁচে থাকার অনুভূতি এমন জিনিস যা তাকে টিকিয়ে রাখে। সে নিজেকে আরও বেশি খুঁজে পেতে চায়। শো এর সেরা অংশ সম্পর্কে রেই এর অভ্যন্তরীণ দ্বন্দ্ব । কাওয়ামটো  বোনেরা রেই এর জীবনে পরিবর্তন নিয়ে আসে এবং সে পরিবারের সাথে তার এক মানবিক সম্পর্ক গড়ে উঠে। ৩ বোনের অধিকাংশ চরিত্র প্রদানের কাজ ২য় সিজনে হয়ে থাকে। তারা এই ধারাবাহিকের অত্যন্ত গুরুত্বপূর্ণ চরিত্র।


তার শ্রেণি শিক্ষক হায়াশিদার সঙ্গে রেই এর সম্পর্ক শো এর হাইলাইটগুলোর একটি, রেই এর চরিত্র কোন মতেই আদর্শরুপে শুরু করে না। তার চরিত্র খুব দুর্বলরুপে প্রকাশ পায় এবং তার শিক্ষক হায়শিদার অবদানে আস্তে আস্তে সে আরও শক্ত হতে শুরু করে  । তার শিক্ষকের সঙ্গে তার কথোপকথনগুলি ধারাবাহিকটির অন্যতম শিক্ষনীয় বস্তু। শিমাদা এবং নিকাইডো রেই এর চরিত্র সংগঠনে গুরুত্বপূর্ণ অবদান পালন করে। এই এনিমটির শ্রেষ্ঠ বৈশিষ্ট্য হলো এখানে প্রায় প্রতিটি চরিত্রকেই গভীরতা প্রদান করা হয়। 


আমাদের বাংলাদেশি দর্শকদের জন্য Sangatsu সময় কাটানোর অনেক ভালো একটি সুযোগ। দক্ষিণ এশিয় দেশগুলো তাদের গল্পে যে ধরনের ছোঁওয়া চায় তা এই এনিমেটিতে আছে। সুতরাং, আমি সবাইকে এনিমেটিকে ধৈর্য সহকারে দেখার উপদেশ দিবো।  বিশেষ করে introverted দের জন্য relatable content দেখার ও বয়স্কদের জন্য এটি তাদের কৈশোরের দিনগুলো নতুন করে উপভগ করার ভালো সুযোগ।

Story:
We return back to March Town, following the story of Rei Kiriyama as his story comes to fruition after digging himself out of the hole he's found himself in for years, turning itsattention to how he's able to help, and give back to those that have given him the support he's wanted and needed for years.


The biggest and most obvious part about this season is that the story is not centered around Rei, which is something I see as a detriment to the series.  He's the main character, and the main character should have the brunt of the story or at least have a major hand in most of it.  As a result of this change, Rei is relegated mostly to a deuteragonist role, often times bouncing in and out of the story's focus where he's either on the main stage, or accompanies someone else who has the spotlight.


It also doesn't help that there're a number of characters that don't ever get their stories finished, and instead get loose ends or are stopped halfway without much development or time left to them.  Kyouko is the biggest culprit of this, and it's honestly a shame considering how the previous season built her up to be an antagonistic and bittersweet character towards Rei, and that hardly got touched upon, which I find odd considering she had a story that existed prior to the series, so having that just vanish in thin air in place of a different character who before his time in the spotlight was just a side character is disappointing to say the least.


But rather than what could've been, what the series is is a show of raw human emotion that feels both genuine and impactful.  The show explores into the various lives and struggles of various other characters, some closer to Rei, others not, providing a broad spectrum that tackles very real personal problems; bullying, expectations, sickness, depression.  The portrayal of these themes through its characters is a gut-wrenching adventure that doesn't let up till its end, gripping the audience through Shinbou's visual storytelling that leaves the viewer with a mix of random feelings of emotions.


By the end of it, 3-gatsu is a whirlwind of emotions that tells the stories of the people of March Town, detailing their hardships and their willingness to break through their problems, fighting tooth and nail through tears and anger, sorrow and sickness, to find themselves in the world that they want to be a part of.  It's a beautiful journey that despite not primarily featuring its main character, makes up in spades with amazing characterization for the parties involved.


Overview:

+ True, raw, human emotion

+ Compelling stories

-  I honestly wish Rei was more involved


Characters:


Rei really only the tail end of everything.  Much of his story is in Season 1, so much of his role this time is to be on the sidelines supporting or helping those close to him in need.  Again, I wish he was more involved or the center for even a little bit tackling some other stories, but what we get from him is the culmination of everything he has been working towards.  The changes are subtle among other things, but the noticeable change in his character brings him into another light that truly feels like he has found himself on the right path, an aspect of the show that seems to still be progressing even beyond his story has finished.


But apart from him, characters like Hina, the middle child of the Kawamoto sisters, and the meijin of the shogi world, Touji Souya, take the spotlight in their own sections of the series, telling their stories through the parts dedicated to them in fashion similar to how Rei's story unfolds.  As per usual with how character driven stories go, there's a clear imbalance to how much weight each of these characters hold, with Hina especially getting a buildup before it hits you hard right in the middle of the show, punching you emotionally without letting up until you finish the episode.


Overview:

+  Great character-based stories

+/- Rei kinda gets sidelined

-  Imbalance in story importance


Art:


Shaft.  Shaft, Shaft, Shaft.  I've stated before that Shaft is the one production company that I have a problem with due to Akiyuki Shinbou's overwhelming presence in the company as its primary director causing me grief because his style of visual storytelling often leaves me scratching my head because I for the life of me cannot understand nor are willing to understand the kind of shit the guy pulls off, especially in the Monogatari series.


But honestly, this is the one show that I can say with certainty would be incomplete without his touch.  The visual metaphors do nothing more but complete the experience.  There are things about animation that you can't do anywhere else, and one of those is to convey a person's emotion in outlandish ways.  Everything about the style from this show; its use of colors contrasting from dramatic black and white to bright and fluffy colors, the distortion of anatomy when someone is distressed, and the blankness of eyes from lack of empathy and emotion.  These little details make the show, and I give Shinbou and his team all the respect I have for bringing this series to life the way that they did despite the flack I give him for some of his other projects.


Overview:

+ Shaft just makes this show.  No questions about it.


Sound:


Alright, I'm gonna say this outright, nothing can beat Bump of Chicken.  The band wrote the songs used in as the OP and ED of the first season as homages to the series as fans.  The power and emotion in their songs is something that personally I don't think can be outmatched.


As a result of this, both sets of OPs and EDs in season two really just aren't great in my opinion.  For such an emotional show, having similar pieces that lead into something that sounds happy go lucky where in scene we physically see the struggles and despair of characters like Hina and Nikaido, I'm sorry, but it just doesn't do it for me.  They're good on their own, but tacking them onto 3-gatsu is not really doing it for me.


Personal Enjoyment:


3-gatsu is definitely a show that places near the top of the list for me.  To be honest, most of what I wrote above is rubbish; really just a formality to give the show the equal analytics I give every show I review.


This show is something you watch for the experience.  You watch it for the characters, the stories, the emotion and gut-wrenching struggles of it all as the people in it give their all to achieve something meaningful in their lives.  The show has very high highs and very low lows, a veritable rollercoaster of emotion as issues like bullying are shown with the painful truth.  Episodes twelve and thirteen will forever stay as two of my favorite episodes of anime period.  I was so enthralled watching it, struggling with my own emotions as I had my own emotions played with, eyes glued to the screen the whole time.  Bar none some of the closest things to perfection in anime that I've ever seen.


Shows like these are things that I hate putting under the analytic scope.  I find that it devalues them by telling others what the show could be rather than what the show actually is.  And that by doing so, I sour my own experience by meticulously nitpicking at everything that's bad so I can separate it by saying what the show succeeds in doing and what it didn't do.  It's for these reasons that the show get my recommendation to watch it.  Just watch it.  Season one, season two, all of it, start to finish.  Rarely does a show portray life in the manner that 3-gatsu does, and even rarer does the show ever scream the word 'human', and all that it entails in trying to succeed in life and find a way to fulfill the gaps that we or others leave in our hearts.  Cause really I just want more people to experience this show and give it the attention that it deserves.

Sangatsu no Lion needs a third season NOW!
Sangatsu no Lion concluded its second season with such force that from now on it makes me wish that a third season was confirmed. If at the end of the first season I said that it had not received enough credit, this time I support it, because Shaft is creating an essential work, an anime jewel.
Based on the manga of Umino Chika, Sangatsu no Lion or 3-gatsu no Lion (March comes in like a Lion), is the story of Kiriyama Rei, a professional Shogi player of 18/19 years. In the first season, Rei was in a place ofdarkness and was taken from it by the sisters Akari, Hina and Momo Kawamoto.


Orphans like him, although they have an aunt and their grandfather, the sisters became the home of the young man in a depression. Since then, Kiriyama not only acquired a new family, but he learned that he was never alone and that he has friends like Harunobu Nikaidō and mentors like Kai Shimada and his ex-teacher Takashi Hayashida.


And these are not the only characters who care about Rei, because even the Kouda, the family that adopted him on the death of their parents, appreciate him ... despite their tense relationship.


Sangatsu no Lion is a profoundly mundane story, except for the status of Rei of Shogi player. It is a story of daily life, which deals with the theme of depression and loneliness. Its first season was a journey of darkness to light for its protagonist, while this season who suffered the darkness were the Kawamoto sisters, especially Hina. Now it was Kiriyama Rei's turn to support them on their way back to the light and it could not be more inspiring.



An anime that everyone should see



Sangatsu no Lion may not be for you. If what you are used to is animes of action and adventure, you will not find any of that here. In the same way if what you appreciate of the anime are the series of science fiction, giant robots, of political subjects, fantasy or intrigue, you will not have what you are looking for either. It does not even work like a sports series, because the practice of sports science that is shogi has a secondary role.


It is not an anime of pretty girls doing cute things, not a harem. It is an authentic pure slice of life, in which there is both drama and comedy, with plenty of space for reflection. Precisely that was one of the points I criticized in the first season, which could abuse those reflective and contemplative moments, but that weakness becomes a strength when the story continues beyond its first 22 episodes.


Similarly, by continuing to see Sangatsu no Lion, who now has Kenjiro Okada at the direction with Akiyuki Shinbo, the weakness of having an open end is also overcome. The conclusion of this season does not represent a real close, but at least the story ends at a point that clearly ends a story arc.


Rei's life changed a lot during this second season, as did the sisters'. Rei finally learned to appreciate his shogi and not to throw his effort to the bottom. That led him to become the rookie champion (players with up to 5th Dan and under 26).


Thus, he was able to confront Touji Souya Meijin, his idol, in a friendly game that revealed that the "God of Shogi" is much more human than it appeared. For her part, Hina had to face that scourge of society that is bullying. In her case to defend a victim, ended up being subjected to the abuse of a group of classmates. Her attitude towards the problem made Rei not only decide to support her to the ultimate consequences, but he himself was saved by Hina's kindness and willpower.


The subject of bullying is being dealt with very often in anime lately, in films like "A Silent Voice". But in Sangatsu no Lion it does not show itself as severely as in that film. The bullying of the series is far less dangerous, although not less malignant. In this series, now of 44 cumulative episodes, the problem is solved quite easily, in large part thanks to the strength of Hina that despite suffering, does not let it overwhelm.


Sangatsu no Lion is an example in this topic and in others, because it has a masterful sensitivity to deal with the different problems it shows. From the health problems of Harunobu to the hard world of professional shogi. This season also followed a subplot about a possible romance for Akari, who met Shimada and Hayashida. It was inevitable, the two thirty year olds were taken by the eldest of the Kawamoto sisters.


In short, the series covered enough terrain of the manga but it left in the bedroom some of the most exciting arcs and one in particular, that if a third season is done, it will end up catapulting this series to my top 5 of all time.


And its merits are not alone in its story, because its art, although perhaps less "impressive", has a subtle sensitivity and beauty, which makes it charming. Its animation is not impressive, and in reality it does not need to be, but it effectively uses its resources. Remember, here there is no action, only very human emotions. Its music also does a formidable job in creating and maintaining a very emotional atmosphere, even in moments of humor. It is not a series that makes you laugh out loud, but it does make you smile a lot and it warms your heart. In short, I need more Sangatsu no Lion. It's a real shame that the season is over and definitely, it's an inspiring anime that everyone should see.


Have you not seen it? What the hell are you waiting for?


And you guys at Shaft, why do not announce a third season for tomorrow?



Summary


Sangatsu no Lion in its second season continues to build the foundation to be an anime masterpiece. It is already close to a 10 and if a third season comes, I would take it there for sure. It's an anime that you MUST see.

Le Studio Shaft a vraiment un style d'animation que l'on pourrait qualifier d'expérimental. Parfois, ils ratent royalement leurs coup, mais honnêtement, avec cette adaptation, ils ont dépassés toutes espérances. J'ai rarement vu un anime qui transcende et met en valeur un manga de manière aussi habile. Déjà, la musique est tout simplement géniale, avec Bump Of Chicken qui délivrent un premier opening/ending et vend du rêve. Le second et troisième opening réussissent l'impensable et sont tout aussi géniaux. (mention spéciale au deuxième ending aussi, quiest :x) Évidement, l'animation est également magnifique, et si originale. Tantôt rappelant une peinture de Van Gogh, tantôt faisant réminiscence au style artistique particulier des dessins du Petit Prince. Bref, un vrai petit bijou d'animation. Connaissant Shaft, j'attendais le moment ou ça devient too much, ou trop arrogant. Ce n'est jamais venu. Au contraire, cet anime est peut-être l'oeuvre la plus humble de ce studio.  



Une des choses que j'ai le plus aimé est que Sangatsu no Lion est une histoire tellement gentille, à propos d'individus super attachants qui tentent de récupérer ce qu'ils ont perdus longtemps avant le début du récit. Rei Kiriyama est vraiment un MC génial. Je l'ai trouvé fascinant dès sa première scène, ou il s'habillait lourdement, comme si des poids étaient attachés à ses membres. Il ne parlait pas, ne souriait pas. Son appartement était vide. Il était seul au monde. On aurait dit que chaque brise manquait de l'emporter. 



Le truc, c'est que son personnage est tellement compréhensible. On s'est tous un peu senti comme Rei dans nos pires journées. Sauf que pour lui, c'est 100 fois plus difficile. Jongler avec une dépression clinique lorsque t'as 17 ans, que tu es tout seul, que tu dois travailler pour payer le loyer d'un appartement ainsi que tes dépenses personnelles, tout en étant aux études et essayant de gérer le stress des compétitions par dessus le marché. Le tout couplé d'une bonne dose de manque de confiance en soi et ce qui semble être un sentiment constant que l'on est un poids et une nuisance dans toutes nos interactions sociales. Rajoutons le fait que Rei n'ai manifestement jamais vraiment fait son deuil par rapport à la mort de sa famille, et on réalise qu'il mérite vraiment une médaille olympique, ainsi un bon câlin. Pauvre gamin. 


Et après, il pense qu'il est nul. ^^ Honnêtement, j'ai envie de le frapper parfois. Mais aussi, lui faire un câlin.


En parlant de dépression clinique, Rei semble avoir une panoplie de particularités psychologiques/psychiatriques manifestement non identifiées par des professionnels. Plusieurs fois en le voyant décrire ses difficultés sociales, j'ai pensé qu'il avait peut-être le syndrome d'Asperger ou une autre forme de trouble autistique. Ce qui m'a titiller vers cette pensée, c'est ses aptitudes sociales limités, son manque d’expressions faciales (les enfants de ses souvenirs l'appelaient ''robot''), son incapacité à bien comprendre les sentiments d'autrui, ses obsessions passagères avec des sujets en particuliers, etc. Bien qu'a la suite de l'histoire, le personnage s'ouvre davantage, c'est seulement avec les individus auxquels il s'est réellement habitué. 


En parlant de Rei qui s'ouvre aux autres, j'ai absolument adoré le développement du personnage au fil de l'histoire. Le voir lier des liens avec les gens alors qu'il a commencé sans amis, sans famille et sans personne dans sa vie était vraiment beau. Mes moments préférés sont probablement ceux où il dîne ou passe du temps avec les Kawamoto. Momo-chan est tout simplement adorable. Akari est incroyablement gracieuse et admirable, et le courage et la force de caractère de Hina me renversent. Toutes les trois sont vraiment attachantes. 


Anyways, to summarize: 


This show made me want to be kind, to become the best person I could be.


It made me want to help a stranger, to hug my mother and to forgive past hurts. 


Kiriyama is such a kind character, I feel for him from the bottom of my heart. His pain is so understandable. 


I really really really hope for a third season, and if there isn't one I will never forget Kiriyama Rei and his friends.

3-Gatsu No Lion is together with Haibane Renmei of those unique works on their genre, the well-known 'Slice of Life'.
'3-Gatsu No Lion 2nd Season' takes everything achieved in the first season to the next level, where it assumes a seriousness and enormous impact with all the objective that the message wants to achieve. Where this series could be called a dose of heartbreakingly positive reality may sound weird, but it does.
Without inquiring much, inthe beginning the series was focused on Rei, but this time we focused on Hina Kawamoto one of the 3 Kawamoto sisters who suffers a serious problem in her school, and doing it is extremely risky, because you risk to the melodrama, the escapism and a lot of possibilities that make it possible that everything will be ruined. But the series makes a huge difference from the beginning, both in the origin of the drama of this arc, in the way in which the protagonists face the problems, in how their actions without leaving the human logic it is very hard to see how hard it is for them face them but are consistent under their own moral, all these aspects could sound in a cold analysis for a subject as delicate as in which the series is focused, but it is extremely important to emphasize them because all this is what makes the characters are extremely human and therefore easy to empathize. All these aspects make the message so powerful and acquire a huge credibility, and all this is further intensified under the monologues of the protagonist, in which we see his evolution and how he finds a concrete goal in life, everything revolving around a game like the 'Shogi'.


Within the 'Shogi' the theme is curious, because the shogi plays an important role in this series, but in turn deconstructs it in an interesting way, since, far from being a series of confrontations to determine a winner, the series around this game of strategy similar to Chess, it gives importance to more than 20 characters in 22 episodes, a very hard task, but that nevertheless is well achieved, in which it is impossible not to become attached and interested in the stories of these professionals of shogi, and therefore in the protagonist, and therefore, worth the redundancy, in the Kawamoto sisters and the entire close circle of Rei Kiriyama.

When I first heard about this anime, I was pretty sceptical to watch it, as I knew nothing about shogi, but after finally finishing it, all I can say is how wrong I was. Everything about this anime is beautifully crafted. I very rarely give shows a 10, because, in my humble opinion, hardly any shows have no notable flaws, but in my honest opinion, this is one of those few. 
Story:
Whilst the story of March Comes in Like a Lion is simple, it marvels in this simplicity. I find manyanimes these days need some form of a gimmick to make a story seem fresh, as so many things have been done, but this show needed none of that. Shogi is merely a canvas for this story to be told on, and a great one at that. My one criticism of this story would be that its pacing was a bit slow to start with, hence a score less than 10, but other than pacing the story was directed fantastically. The story was mostly broken into arcs, focusing on different characters and illustrating how they and Kiriyama develop together. I do think the story really improves in the second season, filling each arc with loads of heartfelt emotions, and an actual impact on me.  Another thing to mention is that even though the whole manga hasn't been adapted (if it's even finished), the ending to the second season was honestly very satisfying, something I rarely see from anime based on ongoing manga. 


Characters:

This is where March Comes in Like a Lion really shines, throwing a huge rug over any little concerns about the story. Each and every character feels fresh and unique and is given time to develop. Whilst Kiriyama isn't necessarily the most entertaining character to ever be created, he feels entirely genuine and extremely relatable. Kiriyama's emotions are complex and evolving, making him feel like a real person, something I very rarely see in anime. His backstory is elegantly handled in a way that really fits into the current story. Being a child with no real family isn't exactly rare for anime protagonists, but what is rare is how delicately this matter is addressed in the anime. Unlike most anime where the protagonist has no family, either simply to enable them to get up to things no family would ever allow, or as a reason for them to be constantly edgy. Whereas in March Comes in Like a Lion, the way Kiriyama responds to his dark past is nuanced, emotional, and realistic.


Enough about Kiriyama, what about the side characters? Well, they are all handled wonderfully, in my honest opinion. Whilst Nikaido is supposed to be Kiriyam's rival, you still end up rooting for both of them. His enthusiasm is heartwarming, and their chemistry is very entertaining. At first, I thought Nikaido was just going to be that annoying guy who insists they will beat you, but over time he really works his way into your heart, not out of pity but out of admiration. The three sisters are just a wonderful combination of wholesomeness, which is a great refreshment in a show that can get pretty heavy. That said they have their depth too, especially Hina who develops brilliantly in her character arc, as she learns to raise her head high and look forward, thanks to Kiriyama. I do wish Akari got some more time to herself, but obviously, with such a vibrant cast, you cannot possibly give everyone the spotlight. Though even with a little spotlight to her, she still warms your heart, as she tries her best to be essentially Hina and Momo's mother, and in part Kiriyama's too.


Not to forget the fellow shogi players, especially Yanagihara and Shimada, who finish the second season off with a beautifully directed title match. Yanagihara's emotions could be felt with each chip, as he struggles amongst the burden of all his friends who had to quit. I was shocked by how deeply his emotions hit me, like a limp bull charging on. 


Overall the characters and how they are developed are what really make this anime shine.


Art and animation:

What can I say other than the art and animation for this anime were stunning. Shaft really pulled out all the stops for this production, as it seemed every frame was handled with the utmost care. The art style was simple yet very unique, and even more expressive. Almost every frame felt like it could be a wallpaper, with a vivid but almost oil painting like colour pallet. I've never seen such a simple art style convey so much emotion and in such nuanced ways. And when the face was not enough, these absolutely breathtaking visuals would display them in what could only be described as pieces of art in their own right. One of my favourite ones was the use of the white cloth wrapping around Yanagihara as he steps into the fire, symbolising the weight of his retired friends as he still pushes forward alone. I mean honestly, those frames would deserve their own place in an art gallery. And it ain't just the art that is breathtaking, the actual animation is wonderfully fluid, and smooth. Even simple shots are done with extra finesse, yet still, you could tell how much time and money went those extra special scenes. Honestly, just scenes of Kiriyama sitting in the wind are as beautiful and fluid as the highest budget sakuga scenes in an average production anime. 


Sound:

I love the soundtrack to this show as well, and whilst it still fits with the theme of simplicity present in most aspects of the show, it is still beautiful and worth listening to. on its own. I probably wouldn't say it is the most unique score I have ever heard, but to say it does its job is an understatement. I am not much of a musical expert, but it definitely fits perfectly at the very least, and really stands out during the key moments.  and The sound effects, voice acting and everything are all stellar as well.


Overall:

Overall I enjoyed the hell out of this show, and was frequently amazed by it; thus I give it a perfect 10. Every single aspect of it was handled with such love and care, and delivered so beautifully, that I feel it would be robbing it to give it anything less. I would highly recommend this show, as it not only a wonderful ride of emotions but one that will actually leave a mark on you. This is anime at its best, and probably the best anime I have seen since it aired.

I don't normally write reviews this long. Ever. Well actually, that’s a lie. I write reviews this long all the time since I typically have a lot to say, but usually in a more sporadic, visceral kind of way that lets me burn off all the emotion I’m feeling after finishing a great show. I guess I should say I don’t normally write reviews this organized. It’s the only show which has ever hit me so hard in my five years of anime-watching to have finally compelled me share my thoughts online in a delicate, considered form instead of just in sputtered, impassioned deep dives with my friends. Because those thoughts are nearly endless, and not enough people have seen this show for me to share that sensation with. So despite how full of raw, unfettered, possessive emotion talking about this show makes me, I promise I’ll try to convey those feelings while still writing something people can actually read (without spoiling anything). But if you are reading this, be prepared for the perhaps the most fervid and possibly most densely worded review you will ever see, because I can barely even contain myself.


Sangatsu no Lion is a perfect show. I say that unironically and without even considering that it could be a subjective idea. It is objective fact. Well, to me anyway. Personal taste aside, this show is a masterpiece to be heralded as one of the greatest works of art of all time in every regard. And I don’t use the term “masterpiece” lightly here. From it’s story, to it’s characters, animation, directing, and sound, everything about it is perfect. It has perfect visual presentation, perfect production quality, perfect thematic setup, perfect narrative execution, perfect character writing, a perfect conclusive ending, and a perfect sense of originality with not a single cliched slip-up to be seen. It is a peak example of modern animation and storytelling, and quite honestly, Sangatsu no Lion in all of it’s splendor doesn’t deserve to even be compared to the rest of anime in terms of the sheer amount of passion and talent that has gone into its creation. Don't get me wrong, I fucking love anime and consume it almost daily, but compared to the base standard most fans of the medium consider good, great, or even excellent, Sangatsu no Lion is leagues above it, on par with some of the greatest animated works in history. It is on a higher level of artistry. Do I sound pretentious enough yet? Good. Because this show made a cynical hyper-critic like me cry more times from pure cinematic resonance than the critically acclaimed, infinitely nostalgic and universally beloved Avatar: The Last Airbender did, a record that went unbroken for over twelve years of my life. It was that powerful. And to me, that makes this show a big fucking deal.


Sangatsu no Lion is truly the whole package like nothing else has been before. With it, Studio Shaft have outdone themselves ten times over, and nearly everyone else in the market. And this is all compounded on top of author Chika Umino’s already phenomenal writing and splendid artwork from the critically celebrated manga. You can intimately feel the pure essence of the hard work that the staff behind the adaptation poured into every ounce of every episode, and the show just oozes with creativity and meaningful intent. It has quite literally the most gorgeously detailed and fluid animation I've ever seen, seemingly unrivaled in all respects and all eras, and some of the most effective and evocative direction ever put to the screen; direction that works with great purpose to give the show its deeply pensive and introspective atmosphere only to then contrast it with equally captivating brighter moments. This combined with an incredibly subtle, yet elaborately moving soundtrack that brims with powerfully cathartic composition allows the show to capture the mood of a scene effortlessly, and rouse even the coldest of hearts to a lingering sense of tender warmth. 


Of course, all of this wouldn’t be possible without the previously mentioned efforts of Chika Umino in authoring the most intimately personal tale I think I’ve ever felt, providing every character with such relatable and poignantly portrayed struggles so as to routinely see myself in their shoes regardless of their specific disposition or circumstances. With its keen understanding of our shared human condition, Sangatsu no Lion weaves a heavily compassionate storyline complete with a stirring, lovable, endlessly endearing and dynamic cast of characters each fitted with their own layered personalities and backgrounds. And it is through these characters and their interactions with one another that the show manages to achieve such a striking abundance of touching and dramatic narrative weight. As the characters all battle with issues of identity, purpose, isolation, and belonging and cling to each other for life, they undergo so much intensive and beautiful growth that it tugs at the very nature of my being. This show is empathy in motion. Watching it constantly filled me with such an immense feeling of love and sadness, yet at the same time, imbued me with a tremendous, indescribable joy, like a happiness I'd never known before. It was like my sense of pathos was being continually reshaped and reaffirmed. It took me over a year to completely finish both seasons of Sangatsu no Lion, the reason being that I never wanted that feeling to end, and feared that I may never find it in another show again once it was over.


Everything about Sangatsu no Lion, from the beginning until the end, thematically and visually, is a roller-coaster of strife, solitude, change, growth, comfort, and triumph, and made for legitimately one of the most engaging and enriching stories I have ever had the pleasure to experience. I laughed, I cried, I smiled, I ached. I was brought low and I was raised high, paralyzed with dreadful sorrow, lifted with joyous cheer and heartened with tender compassion. And at the end of it all, watching the subtle, quiet, gleeful yet bittersweet resolution to all that had happened to these characters I'd come to cherish and identify with so strongly gave me such elation and contentment as to be impossible to convey with mere words alone. As a person who struggles, loves, wants to be loved, yearns for acceptance and strives for the strength to support those who have supported me, seeing these characters undergo all of those same feelings so acutely and with such clear nuance was entrancing. I got to witness them start out as such damaged and fractured people, endure so many harrowing personal challenges, wrestle and try to reconcile with those challenges, find solace and comfort in one another, come to new understandings of themselves and those they hold dear, and ultimately emerge stronger and brighter people, and it left me completely floored. It was stunning (both thematically and visually), and I was transfixed and utterly speechless the whole time. Bear in mind, it definitely was not an easy journey for me or the characters, but even with all the trials, difficulties and somber moments along the way, we came out the other side with all of our scars, still smiling and pushing forward. And I hope you can too.


I don't think I've ever known a work of art quite like Sangatsu no Lion which has so deeply touched my heart, moved me to such profound times of introspection, and found a place within the very soul of my existence. Watching it was a resoundingly poignant and affecting experience for me, one that I will never forget and am sure to carry with me all my life. In this modern era of cheap entertainment, I applaud Studio Shaft and Chika Umino for crafting such an immeasurably heartfelt and evidently passionate work which will forever stand out to me as one of the most breathtaking, impactful and spectacular pieces of artistic media ever made, as well as one of the most uplifting and innately human stories ever told. If you haven't already seen or aren't already watching this show, you aren't just doing yourself a disservice, you're actively missing out on one of the most optically enchanting and emotionally fulfilling experiences you'll ever get the chance to have.

What a truly amazing series. Beautiful is the only way I can describe it. The first season didn't have enough recognition and thus it took me quite some time to notice it. However, I'm really glad this series has finally received the glory it truly deserves.
Story

Rei is still having his own share of obstacles through his shogi career such as strong opponents or his anxiety during matches with the most being the latter. Unlike the firstseason though, which focused on the challenges Rei faced before starting with Shogi and how his life is in general, this season focuses more on the interaction between Rei and the rest of the cast. Thus, this season has considerably more character development than the first one. Also, the three girls now aren't like the rest of the supporting cast, but are having their own arcs with just as much depth especially Hina. 

I loved the first season and I loved this one as well. The story is well presented and, so far, my only complaint about it is the lack of a third season.


Art

I'm glad the art style didn't change since it's more or less the trademark of the series. It's just as beautiful with the colorful, fluffy atmosphere it exudes. It still has warmth, depth and emotional situations. I continued being impressed with Hina's arc and the amount of effort and detail that went through it. Not only the story, the art style somehow felt intended to be used this season with Hina's arc more so than the regular story-line. Those scenic moments with Rei and Hina and the vigorous spirit Hina has made me think the whole series was named after her because she certainly exuded the aura of a lion. You may think of this as an exaggeration, but you'll probably know what I mean once you see it for yourself.


Character Development

I've said it once and I'll say it again. This season was a huge up-scale in terms of character development. They've basically given plenty of depth to most characters while significantly reducing Rei's. We're already very familiar with Rei's personality inside out so that doesn't affect his standing as the protagonist in the series. Plus, it's not like he doesn't get enough screen time. It's just that this season he's more of an onlooker. If there's a third season in progress, I hope they continue with this and add more depth to the rest of the characters just like Hina.


Enjoyment

In simple terms, I enjoyed it. I like the way this series tends to present the story with Rei reading it like a novel. The characters showing multiple sides of their personality. New characters being introduced and really likable ones at that. And not to mention the usual comedy that just slips in-between throughout the whole season. Though there have been many subtle implications about possible ships, I don't know if such a thing would actually happen. I mean, I can't imagine how any of those ships would look like within the style of this anime and I'm afraid it would drop its quality so I guess its just fine with them implicitly mentioned.


Bottom line: If you liked season one even if just a little, then you're probably going to like this season just as much or even more. This anime is really warm and soothing you could use it as a heater, but it's quite slow paced which is to be expected from a chess-like game so that's something to look out for. It's a relaxing piece that feels like literature and I surely recommend it if you're a slice of life fan who's bored of the high school cliché setting.

This review was written after completing season 2 of the show but also covers season 1.

First and foremost, this show is about one thing; love.

Without getting too much into spoiler territory, the show deals with a vast array of problems, with a focus on mental health. Season two of Sangatsu no Lion manages to maintain the brilliant art, sound, and characters of season one while taking the story to a whole new level. From bullying, school life, retirement, and loneliness, no show I have seen is more realistic and down to earth than the second season of Sangastu, which is why it has quickly become my favorite show ever. 
Story: 10/10
The bullying arc that takes up the majority of the second season is a true masterpiece. It shows every aspect of bullying and the impact it has not just on the person being bullied but those around them. It depicts aCatch-22 in trying to stop bullying. Either you be a "bystander" and allow terrible things to occur, or you stand up for the person and risk being bullied yourself. This is the most realistic bullying story in my opinion that puts the viewer in an emotional roller coaster of hate, anger, love, and ultimately tears. 


The arcs that follow are also extremely well done, as we learn about loneliness and isolation that occurs when one reaches the pinnacle of a certain world. We also experience the struggles of retirement and trying to desperately cling to the life you have left. Even if you can't relate to these stories, the story is so well written that you come to understand and feel for the characters undergoing these experiences. 


The most impressive aspect of the story is that despite the genre being "game" it almost feels like you are watching a shonen anime in terms of the character development of the protagonist, Kiriyama Rei. We see him grow as a character through his many interactions, and in turn become a better shogi player (Japanese Chess), similar to how a character in an action anime will become physically stronger in fights. 


Art: 10/10


The art direction in season one was fantastic, and season two does not disappoint. The attention to detail, never being lazy, and the beautiful changes in animation from the normal style to funny cartoon like drawings or wallpaper worthy shots make the show very visually pleasing. Never taking a shot lightly, whether it's a pick up shot or a scene with a side character is something that we can all appreciate. And once again, similar to an action anime, the shogi matches are actually interesting to watch even without understanding anything about shogi. The animation in a shogi match is just as visually jaw-dropping as a fight scene from Mob Psycho 100, Naruto, or Hunter x Hunter. 


Sound: 10/10


The openings in season one called "Answer" and "Sayonara Bystander" are both in my top 10 favorite openings. While the openings in season two are not in my opinion quite as good, they still set the tone for the show very well and are great songs in their own right. The OST's (original soundtracks) are still amazing and are even more memorable because of some of the heartwarming or heartbreaking scenes in this season. 


Characters: 10/10


The character development of both Hina and Rei is some of the best character development I have ever seen. Rei goes from a character I have always liked to my favorite protagonist in anime, and Hina goes from just one of the sisters to a great primary character. While Rei goes from a child to an independent, Hina goes from a little girl to someone who truly cares about others. 


The side characters also bring the story to life. Rei's teacher, club friends, the Kawamoto sisters Grandpa, and Rei's shogi friends all become more and more lovable characters. The hate you feel for certain characters in the bully arc make you love many characters who try to help out and make a difference even more and shows how much courage it takes to not be a bystander. 


Overall: 10/10


Not only does the story get better in season two, but the character development and comedy enhances the amazing soundtrack and animation even more, making the viewer enjoy every aspect of the show. This is thanks to Shaft paying great attention to every character in the show, every scene, every visual, and every sound. The time and effort put into Sangatsu no Lion is apparent, and now with season two being paired with a great story, it made it my favorite season of any show. Now all that's left to do is wait for season three.

Ever since Honey and Clover (HachiKuro), I've become addicted to Chica Umino's work. Not only does she create fantastic characters and stories, her sense of humor is "side-splitting" class and her art style is full of warmth and dynamism. Every volume of March Comes In Like a Lion that came out made me think, "If this isn't made into an anime, this publisher is insane."
Well, I was cheering when the anime adaptation announcement came out with volume... 10? It's been a while.
And Shaft is doing the animation. If it were 10 or 15 years ago I would've had mixed feelings because while Shaft's productions were(and are today) fantastic, in the past they've had problems finishing the animation. Notoriously, they had frozen frames in early broadcasts of Monogatari and Hidamari Sketch, and the aired opening animation of Negima!? was incomplete (the complexity of the finished version made me realize why). Thankfully, Shaft has grown significantly since then, and I would probably have to comb through each frame individually to find even a simple error. Nowadays, I'm completely delighted that Shaft is adapting Umino-sensei's latest saga.


If season 1 is setting the stage for Rei and the Kawamoto sisters (the overture and opening acts if you would), this is act 2, where some serious drama really starts. This is the first turning point for Rei, and this is when we really start to see him shine as a character.


Reading Hina's arc in the manga regularly brought me to tears, and Shaft delivered the anime version masterfully and faithfully. In fact, I struggle to find fault with any element of the production. The visuals are stunning as in season 1 (my mom commented that the backgrounds looked like photographs), the soundtrack is rich with emotion, the acting is superbly directed and performed, every character is detailed and interesting (even the bad guys), and the gags are hilarious. Every moment in both series 1 and 2 is rich with story, even when the audio is silent or has no dialogue-- I've long suspected that there are ex-Gainax staff (or huge fans) working at Shaft, because both studios are/were adept at the use of just audio or just visuals to convey the maximum effect.


In doing so, the entire production demonstrates that even in excruciating circumstances, indeed, circumstances that regularly drive teenagers to take their own lives, there is light and warmth in the world, and maybe, just maybe, the key to addressing the big problems is to give everyone a place of warmth to call home. And "Home" doesn't need to be "where my biological or adoptive family lives", but "someplace where I can always have refuge, where people love me, where they'll face my troubles with me." I've learned in HachiKuro never to underestimate Chica Umino's storytelling, because it is always the complete package: Setting, characters, plot, theme. All elements and the artwork are painstakingly and lovingly made.


Up until season 2 I really wasn't that into the theme songs. Bump of Chicken's performances were great, don't get me wrong, but it wasn't until the very last credit roll of season 1 with Umino-sensei's hand-drawn frames that the lyrics finally hit home. And Yuki's 2 openers are good as in Hachikuro, but her singing style isn't really my cup of tea. But series 2 OP2... now we're talking. Unison Square Garden hit that one out of the park. I can play Haru ga Kite Bokura on repeat all day long.


To sum up, if they don't do a 3rd series, NHK/Shaft and the manga publisher are insane. The next dramatic arc for Rei and the Kawamoto sisters will be a doozy, and I cannot wait to see it animated.

The best quality this show has to offer to a watcher is how well its able to juxtapose the narrative into what is happening on screen. A large chunk of time of this show is spent trying to convey precisely how a character is feeling which is pivotal in how the story is conveyed with no single idea being completely black and white. The struggle with that is being able to convey a subjective idea that isn't binary but 3-gatsu does it masterfully. The second season picks up from where the first left of and while it feels the same, there's also a noticeablechange in focus from season 1's focus on the main protagonists isolation and depression to season 2's focus on the characters on the sidelines. The show radiates this idea and portrays Rei as getting over his depression by doing this which i find masterful. There are three main arcs with the first being the main draw but the other two carry their weight as well. Each one deals with different themes that are still as relatable as the first seasons morals while showing how Rei has changed since. Each character feels fully fleshed out and are believable enough that they don't give of a feeling of only existing in this story and have lives outside the narrative, which is helped by this being a slice of life show but even then, these characters are much better written then some run of the mill show. The greatest loss that this show suffered was subsequently caused by the same aspect I was praising it for in the beginning. While I found the switch of focus off of Rei to be brilliant, a lot of the first seasons story telling was through the actual game of shogi. Whenever I watch a show that features a sport, I always look to see how the writers use it as a medium for characterization or development of themes. That is what shaft accomplished with the first season. However with the shift away from Rei, it was only logical for the creators to shift away from using Shogi as well which was dissapointing to say the least. It was only featured a bit and not exactly used like it was in the first season.
